revision.text: {{Orphan|date=October 2015}} This '''timeline of paleontology in Michigan''' is a chronologically ordered list events in the history of [[paleontological]] research occurring within or conducted by people from the [[U.S. state]] of [[Michigan]]. ==19th century== [[File:Platygonus compressus Harvard.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''[[Platygonus compressus]]'' skeleton.]] ===1830s=== '''[[1839 in paleontology|1839]]''' * The state's first scientifically documented [[American mastodon]] remains were discovered. ===1870s=== '''[[1877 in paleontology|1877]]''' * Five Pleistocene [[peccaries]] (''[[Platygonus compressus]]'') were discovered in an [[Ionia County]] [[peat bog]] located near the town of [[Belding]]. The find was credited to L. N. Tuttle and the specimens are now catalogued as UMMP 7325. ==20th century== ===1900s=== '''[[1903 in paleontology|1903]]''' * Wagner reported Tuttle's peccaries to the scientific literature. ===1910s=== [[File:Armand de Montlezun (1841-1914) Bacalum Morse.jpg|thumb|right|[[Walrus]] [[penis bones]] from Alaska.]] '''[[1914 in paleontology|1914]]''' * Ezra Smith made another interesting Pleistocene-aged discovery, finding the fossil [[penis bone]] of a [[Late Pleistocene]] [[walrus]] seven miles northwest of [[Gaylord, Michigan|Gaylord]]. The specimen was referred to the genus ''[[Odobenus]]'' and is now catalogued as UMMAA 490. ===1920s=== '''[[1923 in paleontology|1923]]''' * O. P. Hay reported the presence of two identifiable species and one indeterminate form of [[mammoth]] whose fossils had been found in Michigan. '''[[1925 in paleontology|1925]]''' * Hinsdale reported Smith's walrus penis bone to the scientific literature. [[File:Bowhead whales swimming in Lingolm strait by Vladislav Raevskii.JPG|thumb|right|Modern [[bowhead whales]].]] '''[[1927 in paleontology|1927]]''' * Excavations for a new schoolhouse in [[Oscoda, Michigan|Oscoda]] turned up a Late Pleistocene fossil rib that may have belonged to a [[bowhead whale]] of the genus ''[[Balaena]]''. The specimen is now catalogued as UMMP 11008. ===1930s=== '''[[1930 in paleontology|1930]]''' * Hussey publish the first scientific paper on the Michiganian whale fossils curated by the University of Michigan Museum of Paleontology. ===1940s=== '''[[1940 in paleontology|1940]]''' * MacAlpin calculated that a total of 117 American mastodon specimens had been discovered in Michigan. '''[[1949 in paleontology|1949]]''' * ''October:'' A third lower premolar from a Pleistocene [[elk]] was discovered in [[Berrien County, Michigan|Berrien County]]. ===1950s=== '''[[1953 in paleontology|1953]]''' * Handley tentatively referred the rib discovered in Oscoda during the 1927 schoolhouse excavation to the genus ''Balaena''. He also reported the discovery of an [[Arkonan]]-aged [[rorqual]] rib of the genus ''[[Balaenoptera]]''. The fossil had been discovered upright in the sand during the excavation of a cellar in [[Genesee County, Michigan|Genessee County]]. Handley also reported the discovery of another walrus fossil, a skull catalogued as UMMP 32453 found in a [[Makinac Island]] gravel deposit. Handley also reported the discovery of [[sperm whale]] ribs and a vertebra from Lenawee County. ===1960s=== [[File:Mammuthus columbi Sergiodlarosa.jpg|thumb|right|Restoration of a Columbian or "Jefferson" mammoth]] '''[[1961 in paleontology|1961]]''' * ''August:'' Larry Kickels collected the third right upper molar of a [[Jefferson mammoth]] from a gravel layer 100 feet below the surface of Berrien County, near the town of [[Watervliet, Michigan|Watervliet]]. '''[[1962 in paleontology|1962]]''' * ''September 18'' Larry Kramer discovered a lower mastodon molar now catalogued as GRPM 12540 in [[Paris Township, Michigan|Paris Township]] along Buck Creek. * Skeels reported that since MacAlpin's 1940 review of Michigan mastodon discoveries 49 new finds had been made. He also performed the first census of local mammoth remains, noting that 32 Jefferson mammoths had been discovered in Michigan. * Hatt also formally described a partial mastodon skull now catalogued as CIPS 827 which had been discovered in Pontiac. * Fossils of a Jefferson mammoth were discovered in Gratiot County. '''[[1963 in paleontology|1963]]''' * Oltz and Kapp reported the 1962 Gratiot County mammoth discovery to the scientific literature. * Hatt reported the discovery of a mammoth molar in [[Oakland County]] to the scientific literature. '''[[1964 in paleontology|1964]]''' * ''May:'' Fred Berndt discovered lower jaw fragments and the second right molar of a lower mastodon jaw, in [[Lincoln Charter Township, Michigan|Lincoln Township]].{{cite journal |url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Recent+discoveries+of+fossil+vertebrates+in+the+lower+Peninsula+of...-a097873195 |title=Recent discoveries of fossil vertebrates in the lower Peninsula of Michigan |journal=Michigan Academician |volume=XVIII |issue=3 |pages=431-63 |date=September 22, 2003 |last1=Holman |first1=J. Alan |last2=Fisher |first2=Daniel C. |last3=Kapp |first3=Ronald O. |accessdate=August 18, 2017}} The remains are now catalogued as UMMP 49425. '''[[1965 in paleontology|1965]]''' * The [[Petoskey stone]], which is made of fossil [[coral]], was designated the [[state stone]] of Michigan. ==21st century== ===2000s=== '''[[2002 in paleontology|2002]]''' * The [[American mastodon]], ''[[Mammut americanum]]'' was designated the Michigan [[state fossil]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Mammut americanum'' (Kerr). American Mastodon", p. 214. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Physeter'' sp. Sperm Whale", p. 212. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Balaenoptera'' sp. Rorquals", p. 213. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Cervus canadensis'' Erxleben. Elk", p. 215. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "Whales", p. 212. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''? Balaena'' sp.", p. 213. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Mammuthus jeffersoni'' (Osborn). Jefferson Mammoth", p. 214. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Odobenus'' sp.", p. 212. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Platygonus compressus'' (Le Conte). Peccary", p. 215. [[#Wilson|Wilson]] (1967); "''Mammut americanum'' (Kerr). American Mastodon", p. 213. }} ==Works cited== {{refbegin}} * {{cite journal |ref= Wilson |last= Wilson |first= R. L. |year= 1967 |title= The Pleistocene Vertebrates of Michigan |journal= Papers of the Michigan Academy of Science Arts and Letters |volume= 52 |pages= 197–257}} {{refend}} {{commons category|Paleontology in Michigan}} {{Wikisource portal|Paleontology in the United States#Michigan}} [[Category:Paleontology in Michigan]] [[Category:Paleontology timelines|Michigan]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Zénobe Gramme |image =Zénobe Gramme 1893.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Zénobe Gramme by [[Nadar (photographer)|Nadar]], 1893 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1826|4|4}} |birth_place = [[Amay|Jehay-Bodegnée]], Belgium |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1901|1|20|1826|4|4}} |death_place = [[Bois-Colombes]], France |death_cause = |resting_place = [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]] |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Belgium|Belgian]] |other_names = |known_for = [[Gramme dynamo]] |education = |employer = |occupation = [[electrical engineer]] |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relatives = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Zénobe Théophile Gramme''' (4 April 1826 – 20 January 1901) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[electrical engineer]]. He was born at [[Jehay-Bodegnée]] on 4 April 1826, the sixth child of Mathieu-Joseph Gramme,<ref name="hyperpaysagedejehay1">{{cite web|url=http://www.hyperpaysagedejehay.be/zenobe2.htm |title=Zénobe Gramme : un enfant du pays |publisher=Hyperpaysagedejehay.be |date=8 June 2008 |accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref> and died at [[Bois-Colombes]] on 20 January 1901. He invented the [[Gramme machine]], a type of [[direct current]] [[dynamo]] capable of generating smoother (less [[Alternating current|AC]]) and much higher voltages than the dynamos known to that point.
==Career== Gramme was poorly educated and semi-literate throughout his life. His talent was in handicraft and when he left school became a joiner. After moving to Paris he took a job as a model maker at a company that manufactured electrical equipment and there became interested in technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madehow.com/inventorbios/61/Z-nobe-Th-ophile-Gramme.html|title=Zénobe Théophile Gramme Biography (1826-1901)|publisher=How products are made|accessdate=6 March 2017}}</ref>
Having built an improved dynamo Gramme, in association with [[Hippolyte Fontaine]], opened a factory to develop the device. The business, called Société des Machines Magnéto-Électriques Gramme, manufactured the Gramme dynamo, Gramme ring, Gramme armature and other devices. In 1873 a Gramme dynamo was exhibited at the Vienna exhibition.
He was made an officer of the National Order of the [[Legion of Honour]] in 1877. In 1888 he was awarded the last of the valuable [[Volta Prize]]s by the French government.
==Gramme machine as motor== In 1873 he and [[Hippolyte Fontaine]] accidentally discovered that the device was reversible<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/212450/Hippolyte-Fontaine |title=Hippolyte Fontaine (French engineer) – Encyclopædia Britannica |publisher=Britannica.com |date= |accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref> and would spin when connected to any DC power supply. The Gramme machine was the first usefully powerful [[electrical motor]] that was successful industrially. Before Gramme's inventions, electric motors attained only low power and were mainly used as toys or laboratory curiosities.
In 1875, [[Nikola Tesla]] observed a Gramme machine at the [[Graz University of Technology]]. He conceived the idea of using it for [[alternating current]] but was unable to develop the idea at this time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fi.edu/learn/case-files/tesla/seeds.html |title=Nikola Tesla: Planting Seends |publisher=Fi.edu |date= |accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref>
==Family== In 1857 he married Hortense Nysten who was a widow and mother of a daughter, Héloïse. Hortense died in 1890.<ref name="hyperpaysagedejehay1"/>
==Death and tributes== Gramme died at [[Bois-Colombes]], France, on 20 January 1901 and was buried in [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]].
In the city of [[Liège (city)|Liège]] there is a graduate school of engineering, l'[[Institut Gramme]], named after him.
In 2005 he ended at the 23rd place in the election of ''[[Le plus grand Belge]]'' (The Greatest Belgian), the television show broadcast by the [[French (language)|French]]-speaking [[RTBF]] and based on the [[BBC]] show [[100 Greatest Britons]].
A958 ''Zenobe Gramme'', (1961–), a sailing ship of the [[Belgian Navy]] used for training, is named after him.
== Honours == * Commander in the [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Order of Leopold]]. * Officer in the [[Legion of Honour]].
